title: Literary landmarks of Edinburgh,
author: Hutton, Laurence
snippet: CAMPBELL — BROUGHAM 6ienchantment to the view" was conned on CaltonHill, while history proves that the poem itself waswritten in Alison Square, " in the second floor of astair on the north side of the central archway, withwindows looking partly into the Potterrow and partly into Nicolson Street." This house is still standing, although certain portions of the tenement ofwhich it formed a part were removed when MarshallStreet was cut through that part of the town in1876. " During the period of the poet's occupancy,".writes Mr. Anthony C. McBryde, " and until abouttwenty years since, the tenement or block dividedAlison and Nicolson Squares, but gave access toboth by a pend, or archway."

title: New North Church, Edinburgh
author: Livingston, Josiah.
snippet: When the Cowgate Church was recognised as a constituent member of the Presbytery, and consequentlytook upon itself its mission operations without requiring aid, the New North, by agreement with theneighbouring congregations, took up a district inBristo, and a student missionary and various membersvisited the families and gathei-ed the children into aMission Sabbath School and Children's Church meeting in a hall in Forrest Road. This work was largelydeveloped when in 1880 the congregation, at a cost ofbetween £3000 and £4000, acquired commodious andthoroughly suitable premises, the Halls in MarshallStreet. In these the various meetings connected withthe Congregation and Mission have been carried oncomfortably and with much success; and the Missionhas not only been blessed to many families in thedistrict, but has reacted in much blessing to the congregation itself, binding the membership togetherby common labour and association.

This house is still standing, although certain portions of the tenement ofwhich it formed a part were removed when MarshallStreet was cut through that part of the town inI876. "During the period of the poet's occupancy,"writes Mr. Anthony C. title: Literary landmarks of Edinburgh,
author: Hutton, Laurence
snippet: Mrs. M'Lehose, deserted by her husband, lived, inBurns's time, with two young children in General'sEntry, which lay between the Potterrow and BristoStreet; but no houses dating back to Clarinda's daystand within a stone's-throw of Clarinda's ﬁat. Thesomewhat pretentious public school on MarshallStreet was built upon General's Entry. On the 14th of January, I787, Burns wrote: "Iwent to a Mason lodge yesternight, where the M. W.Grand Master Charteris and all the Grand Lodge ofScotland visited.
